nodes.label: Event

properties.description: Tea Act of 1773 passed, which granted the British East India Company a monopoly on tea sales in the American colonies.

nodes.label: Event

properties.description: Samuel Adams and the Sons of Liberty led American colonists in boarding British ships and dumping 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor.

nodes.label: Event

properties.description: The Tea Act imposed taxation without colonial representation in Parliament.

nodes.label: Event

properties.description: Violation of fundamental principles of self-governance due to taxation without representation.

properties.description: Creation of economic pressure on local merchants who were undercut by the monopoly.

properties.description: Ideological mobilization around constitutional principles.

properties.description: Initiation of the path to armed conflict.

properties.description: Predicted increases in British trade enforcement activity.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: The revolution was primarily driven by colonists' principled opposition to taxation without representation.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: Constitutional concerns override economic interests as motivations for colonial resistance.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: The presence of constitutional language in private correspondence reflects genuine beliefs rather than political rhetoric.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: The economic grievance hypothesis: the mechanism operates through material interests rather than ideological commitment, with merchants using constitutional rhetoric to disguise self-interested opposition to British trade policies.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: A coordinated communication network existed among colonial leaders, suggesting a more systematic organization than previously recognized.

nodes.label: Hypothesis

properties.description: Enlightenment ideas influenced colonial thinking.

nodes.label: Causal_Mechanism

properties.description: The mechanism through which the Tea Act led to rebellion involves: (1) Tea Act imposing taxation without representation, violating self-governance principles; (2) This creating economic pressure on merchants and ideological mobilization; (3) Groups channeling discontent into organized resistance; (4) Resistance culminating in direct action against British property (e.g., Boston Tea Party).

nodes.label: Causal_Mechanism

properties.description: The imperial control mechanism is the process by which legislative components (like the Tea Act) create economic and political pressures necessary to test colonial loyalty and extract revenue from American territories.

nodes.label: Alternative_Explanation

properties.description: The revolution was primarily driven by colonial merchants' economic interests, with wealthy merchants manipulating popular sentiment to protect their smuggling operations and avoid British taxes.
key_predictions: Disproportionate merchant leadership in revolutionary activities
Focus on trade policy over representation issues

nodes.label: Alternative_Explanation

properties.description: Colonial elites deliberately manufactured popular outrage to advance their own political ambitions.
key_predictions: Revolutionary rhetoric would be concentrated among the educated elite rather than emerging organically from popular sentiment.

nodes.label: Alternative_Explanation

properties.description: French agents and financial support were the primary drivers of colonial rebellion, seeking to weaken their British rivals.
key_predictions: Early French involvement and financial backing before 1775

nodes.label: Alternative_Explanation

properties.description: European balance-of-power considerations influenced colonial resistance more than previously recognized.

nodes.label: Actor

properties.name: Samuel Adams
properties.role: Principal organizer, Colonial leader, Son of Liberty
properties.beliefs: British rule fundamentally violated colonial rights.
properties.intentions: Mobilize mass resistance against British authority.
properties.constraints: Need to maintain legitimacy and avoid alienating moderate colonists.

properties.source_text_quote: King George III viewed the colonies as subordinate territories that existed to benefit Britain. He intended to maintain imperial control and extract revenue...

properties.source_text_quote: Correspondence evidence disproves the occurrence of Samuel Adams meeting with French agents before 1775, as detailed postal records and diplomatic correspondence show no such contact existed during the critical period. ...Absence of French support before 1776 refutes the external influence theory (Failed Smoking Gun for French involvement)
properties.reasoning: By definitively disproving early French involvement (a 'Failed Smoking Gun' for the external influence theory), this evidence removes a major competing explanation, thereby strengthening the constitutional principle hypothesis.
